{
  "concepts": [
    {"term": "alpha decay", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "beta decay", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "beta-minus", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "beta-plus", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "positron emission", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "gamma decay", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "electron capture", "category": "physics"}
  ],
  "evidence": [
    "Radioactive isotopes can decay through several different mechanisms",
    "the first is alpha decay, the second is beta decay",
    "which includes both beta-minus and beta-plus, or positron, emission",
    "the third is gamma decay",
    "the fourth is electron capture",
    "Each of these processes describes a different way in which an unstable nucleus transforms into a more stable state, releasing radiation in the process"
  ]
}

evidence: Radioactive isotopes can decay through several different mechanisms
the first is alpha decay, the second is beta decay
which includes both beta-minus and beta-plus, or positron, emission
Each of these processes describes a different way in which an unstable nucleus transforms into a more stable state, releasing radiation in the process
